content.content:
[Content truncated]... worm, _Cephalothrix simula_, Hiroshima Bay, tetrodotoxin, HPLC-FLD, ESI-MS, IR, NMR, GC-MS
1\. Introduction
----------------
Nemerteans are mostly marine, soft-bodied, vermiform invertebrates distributed worldwide, often inhabiting under rocks, among sessile organisms or within various sediments along coastal areas \\]. With approximately 1200 known species \\], they comprise the phylum Nemertea, which is classified into three subgroups, Palaeonemertea, Pilidiophora (=Heteronemertea + _Hubrechtella_ and related forms) and Hoplonemertea \,,\]. They are generally carnivorous, with no morphological or behavioral means of protection against potential predators. Their food items so far studied include, among others, annelids, crustaceans and mollusks \,,,,,\]. They rely on various toxic or noxious chemicals for their defense and predation \,\]. The earliest report that nemerteans possessed toxins was by Bacq \,\], who discovered two neurotoxins, each from (1) _Amphiporus lactifloreus_ and _Drepanophorus crassus_ and (2) _Lineus longissimus_ and “_Lineus lacteus_” (=_Ramphogordius lacteus_). He suggested that these substances, which he called “amphiporine” and “némertine”, respectively, served in a defensive role, rather than being offensive venoms, such as those frequently associated with the prey captured by a characteristic eversible organ, the proboscis. This suggestion was supported by Kem \,,\] who reported that 70% of the total anabaseine present in the hoplonemertean, _Paranemertes peregrina_, was located in its integument. Species of _Amphiporus_, _Cerebratulus_, _Lineus_ and _Tetrastemma_ have also been found to contain other toxins, including neurotoxic polypeptides and pyridyl alkaloids \,\]. Nemerteans are unique among metazoans in possessing an eversible proboscis, housed in a coelom-homologous \,\], fluid-filled body cavity, the rhynchocoel. In marine, free-living nemerteans, the proboscis is used in prey capture...[Content truncated]

A video showing a bizarre ability of a worm is gaining traction on social media. In a clip, a man is seen tapping on the body of the "alien-like" species and within a few seconds it spits out a tree-like structure. While the clip can disgust some users, others found it "cool and creepy" at the same time. The species in question is a ribbon worm, very slim and only a few millimetres wide. Many have patterns of yellow, orange, red and green colours.
The worm seen in the video posted on Twitter shows a red-coloured worm, which looks like a jelly. There is a small black dot at its mouth.
The worm tries to avoid the taps from the man by moving around, but after 4-5 attempts, it spits out the bizarre tree-like structure.
The 8-second clip, posted on Twitter, has shocked the users. "That is what nightmares...[Content truncated]

Query1.snippet: Nemertearibbon worms(Also: proboscis worms) · Diversity · Geographic Range · Habitat · Systematic and Taxonomic History · Physical Description · Development.

content.content:
[Content truncated]...als is unique to the phy­lum. The pro­boscis is an elon­gate, ever­si­ble, blind tube, sur­rounded by the rhyn­chocoel (a fluid filled, hy­dro­sta­tic cav­ity) and ad­di­tional mus­cle lay­ers, in­clud­ing the pro­boscis re­trac­tor mus­cle at the pos­te­rior wall of the rhyn­chocoel. It is ei­ther con­nected di­rectly to the foregut or opens through a pro­boscis pore. In many species, the pro­boscis bears stylets, struc­tures typ­i­cally 50 to 200 µm in length, each shaped like a nail. Ne­merteans may use their pro­boscises for lo­co­mo­tion, though its pri­mary func­tion is in prey cap­ture. Stylets are often lost dur­ing prey cap­ture and must be re­placed as the an­i­mal grows; they are con­tin­u­ously formed by spe­cial­ized cells (stelo­to­cytes) within re­verse stylet sacs, where they are stored. Sticky, some­times even toxic sub­stances are pro­duced by the pro­boscis in order to trap and im­mo­bi­lize prey. (; ; )
Sex­ual di­mor­phism is rare but not un­known in ne­merteans. Some sex­u­ally di­mor­phic char­ac­ter­is­tics in­clude body size (fe­males larger), dif­fer­ences in gonad lo­ca­tion, along with sex­ual ap­pendages in males and col­oration dif­fer­ences dur­ing breed­ing sea­son (males tend to be brighter in color). (; )
*   
*   
*   sexes alike
*   female larger
*   male more colorful
*   sexes shaped differently
*   
### De­vel­op­ment
Ne­mertean fer­til­iza­tion may be ex­ter­nal or in­ter­nal. Egg cases or cap­sules are formed, in which de­vel­op­ment oc­curs. Some ter­res...[Content truncated]

Query2.title: A ribbon worm explores its surroundings with its proboscis | The Kid ...
Query2.snippet: Jun 9, 2015 ... The tongue-like organ can shoot out to capture prey—and in certain species, it's sticky and will entangle a clam, sea slug, or another worm. The ...

content.content:
What’s super bright green, explores its surroundings with a really long pink tendril, and has become a viral sensation since  by a fisherman in the Penghu Islands, Taiwan? _:_
The creature in question is a type of , or ribbon worm, called _Lineus fuscoviridis_, says Jon Norenburg, chair of invertebrate zoology at the Smithsonian’s Natural History Museum in Washington, D.C. This harmless species ranges from Japan to the Philippines and is fairly common in tropical coastal waters, he says. The animal in the video “probably crawled out of something brought out of the water,” Norenburg explains, like a porous rock, a large clump of seaweed, or even an old tire…
So what about that pink thing writhing around on the dock in the video? It’s a , one of the defining features of this group of ribbon worms. The tongue-like organ can shoot out to capture prey—and in certain species, it’s sticky and will entangle a clam, sea slug, or another worm. The ribbon worm will then engulf its victim whole.
And there are over 1,100 species of ribbon worm in the world! , we can see  internet-famous ribbon worm here:

QA.Question: What specific characteristics of the proboscis in the video support the claim of it being tree-like?
QA.Answer: The claim that the proboscis displayed by the ribbon worm in the video is tree-like is supported by several specific characteristics observed in the evidence. 1. **Branching Structure**: The tree-like appearance of the proboscis likely refers to its branching characteristics, which may resemble the limbs of a tree. This is suggested by the description of the worm being able to spit out a "tree-like structure," which indicates that the proboscis can extend and possibly form branches or extensions that mimic a tree's silhouette [Query 1_evidence 2]. 2. **Eversion Mechanism**: The proboscis of ribbon worms is eversible, meaning it can be turned inside out and extended quickly to capture prey. This action may create a temporary structure that, when fully extended, could visually resemble the rough outline of a tree. According to biological studies, an eversible proboscis enables these worms to capture prey with explosive force, allowing for swift movements that could amplify its tree-like appearance during display or hunting [Query 1_evidence 1]. 3. **Dynamic Movement**: The highly developed muscles of ribbon worms enable them to contract and manipulate their bodies, which may affect how the proboscis is displayed. In the video, the worm attempts to avoid being touched before it extends its proboscis. This dynamic reaction could also contribute to the perception of the proboscis as tree-like as it sways or moves in response to stimuli, much like branches reacting to the wind [Query 1_evidence 2]. Overall, these characteristics of the proboscis — its ability to branch out, the mechanics of eversion, and dynamic muscular control — collectively support the claim of it resembling a tree-like structure.
